==Japanese==
{{ja-kanjitab|あま|くだ|o2=り|yomi=kun}}

===Etymology===
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=あまくだり|天|tr1=ama|t1=heaven, heavens|降る|alt2=降り|tr2=kudari|t2=the {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei|pos=stem or continuative form}} of verb {{ja-l|降る}} ''kudaru'' “to descend, to come down”}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

===Pronunciation===
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|訓読み|Kun'yomi}}
* {{ja-accent-common|h|あ|まくだり}}<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[a̠ma̠kɯᵝda̠ɾi]}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|あまくだり}}

# Coming down to earth from heaven.
# The entity making such a visit; an [[avatar]].
# In Japan's postwar period, the practice of awarding a high-level bureaucrat with a high-paying job after retirement (also spelled {{l|ja|天下り}}): a kind of {{m|en|golden parachute}}. Related to {{m|en|regulatory capture}}.

====Synonyms====
* {{sense|someone descended from heaven}} {{ja-l|天降人|あまくだりびと|amakudaribito}}; {{ja-l|天人}} ({{ja-l|てんにん}}, {{ja-l|||tennin}}; {{ja-l|あまびと}}, {{ja-l|||amabito}}; {{ja-l|あめひと}}, {{ja-l|||amehito}})
* {{sense|avatar of a god}} {{ja-l|化身|けしん|keshin}}, {{ja-l|権化|ごんげ|gonge}}
